so i'm usually here coaching my dog to go potty with a pink poop bag in hand.  i've never had to buy any of the 50 round things (i can't say b-a-l-l out loud) since the usual stray green balls sail over the tennis courts.  once my dog gets a few chews in and i yell a few, "drop it!" most of the folks don't want it back.

uh, you know the newbies  are the ones who sit on the doggy side of the park.  the dog owners all know that not one blade of grass as been untouched by poop or pee.  i'm usually there yelling, "heads!" since i'm throwing the ball so far with the chuck-it toy.  i've gotten a few shout outs that i should join the baseball team or "nice arm."  well, that is until my doggie hurt his knee.  the doggie side is a little uneven in the ground.  

there is a playground in the back with bbq grills for our bark-b-qs.  yeah, i once brought bone shaped cookies to one of these parties.  i thought i was so cool but they morphed in the oven into rude looking things.  i got some dirty looks but they did go quickly.

great views if you can withstand the winds from the heights and mist from the marina.  my morning hairdo usually  goes from cute marilyn curls to bon jovi by the time i finish the morning walk.  but the views haven't stopped amazing me.  i hope they never do.
author: Anh V.

description: It's such a great park. I walked here from Montgomery Bart yesterday and it was just perfect. Great grassy field, two tennis courts, a spectactular view of the bay, and hella dogs. Yesterday was my first time going here and I will definitely be returning soon.
author: Christopher B.

description: I am SO lucky this park is in walking distance of my apt. I was worried moving to the city from the south bay would mean my Lexi girl would have to get use to concrete fun, but this park and many others in pac heights are super dog friendly and all the owners are tolerant of my little social butterfly.
author: Alicia K.

description: Although I love Alta Plaza Park, you may read my review if you like, Lafayette is my favorite among the two. It might not have the view like Alta Plaza, but it has something better on a sunny weekend...and that's people! So for a people watcher like myself it's marvelous. I go to Whole Foods grab a sandwich, a magazine and head to Lafayette to pretend to read my magazine but really watch people. Now the tennis courts aren't as nice as Alta Plaza, but you are more likely to see and hear those crazy Parrots of Telegraph Hill flying from tree to tree. Cool.
author: Amanda P.

description:
I would like to give this five stars, but minus one for a reason i will get to in a minute. The park has tennis courts, you can actually grill out in it, people laying out and working on their tan, a place for kids to play, wonderful views and plenty of quiet places to get away. My wife and I loved it so much that when we moved here, we wanted to be close by. Imagine our happiness when we found a place that looks out over the park (the quiet side on Gough) - we are sooo cool. We moved in, got settled and were so pleased with our view (You can see the bay too if you stand on your tip toes, and you're already tall), watching all the nannies walking their paychecks an what not and of course all the people walking their dogs. I love dogs, I have always had them - Newfoundlands, labs, Irish setters - big dogs. Well, after about a week, i began to notice a pattern. People tend to come home about quarter to 5 (I don't know what it is about these short hours on the west coast) and naturally, every body's Fido's needs to get rid of breakfast. So for about the next two hours, we have the most beautiful view of dogs taking dumps. I can't tell you how many times i have seen some dog scrunch up and unload while i am having dinner. In fact, i have come to 'know' this pug (that has a striking resemblance to its owner) that (i swear) is smiling every time it takes a dump! I mean really! so that's worth at least half a star (maybe one in and of itself) and the other drawback is that i get to watch sweet romantic couples stopping by for a nice picnic or setting down to eat their lunch. This of course would we a great thing - if not for the fact that they tend to sit right where the pug usually unloads every night at 5:45! 

Seriously, this is a great park! The dog thing is really only a vent on my part. My daughter loves it. We just don't roll around in the 'lush' grass.
author: The Man M.

description: Mini doggie heaven so close to home!  I love bringing my little Roxie to Lafayette Park.  With rare exception, the dogs (and owners) who come to this park are well-behaved and don't try to eat my little munchkin.  There's a little trail that goes almost all the way around the perimeter of the park, which gives my dog the exercise she needs.  The rest of the time is spent with her jumping into people's laps.  And there's plenty of space for my dog and my boyfriend's dog to run around to let off some steam.  The only things I would change about this place are adding a fence so that I wouldn't worry about the little one running off (which she very rarely does) and make the drainage better (gets a bit swampy after the rain).  I've heard there are plans to do a bunch of construction/renovation/whatever in the future, but I really hope that if that happens that they preserve enough doggie space.
author: Danielle B.

description: Bust out your poodle, your fur coat, and your 55 year old rich lady costume, cause we're going to Lafayette Park!
author: Geronimo G.

description: I love this park because it has some incredible views, is surrounded by beautiful Victorians in Pacific Heights, and of course has lots of people walking their dogs. It's also walking distance to mansions, shops, and some nice cafes: so it makes a great afternoon walk about town. But it is also just an incredibly breathtakingly beautiful place.
author: Risa F.

description:
there are so many great things about this park! 
first the views in all directions are amazing on a clear day or any day
second there is a perfect grass to forest ratio 
   -tons of grass to lay around in (and for the dogs!) and trees to hug
and there are really cute dogs that love this park
during christmas everyone in the neighborhood with a dog made an ornament for their dogs with their pictures on them, and then they made one of the trees like a dog christmas tree!!!  sooo cute
there are tennis courts if youre into that.
and the biggest magnolia tree ive ever seen,
okay so the point is if you like parks go here!
author: cate d.

description: This has been the home to my dog Inky, R.I.P. and is now presided over by the gorgeous, the beautiful, Ms. Bayside Wind in the Willows, or Willow to those who know her. Many think she is the reincarnation of Mahatma Ghandi. So patient and kind. What's that girl? Oh, she says she likes to sniff under the willow tree near the entrance on Octavia. Oh, she just took a big deuce....
author: Sam S.

description: Two very good tennis courts.  Darn if I don't love a sport that encourages wearing a skirt while playing. Don't let the glasses fool you, T-bone kicks my ass here on a regular basis.
author: L W.

description: Dogs really like this park, too. If you like to dog watch, come here and sit on the benches half way up the hill on the West side. It will be lovely and make you smile.
author: miss lisa k.

description: Aw, this is my favorite park. It smells like eucalyptus and you can see the Bay. I end my run up Octavia street at this beautiful spot. This is also where my husband and I had a breakfast picnic for our wedding guests on the morning after. I love to stand under the trees around sunset and admire the Bay. Especially when I have a glass of wine in hand!
author: Sahra H.

description: Great dog park. The people (and dogs) that go here are fantastic.  It would be nice if there was a lighted area for winter nights with the dogs.
author: Christen D.

description: The home of Pug Sundays has two nice tennis courts.  They are private with a fence around each.  The downside is that these are popular courts and there is almost always a wait. It's a great location for watching dogs and for grabbing lunch after a fierce game.
author: T-Bone L.

description: This is our go-to local park for taking Esther (our Weimaraner) out for a good run and plenty of socializing.  In the evenings there's almost always a good crowd.  Sometimes it seems like it's all small dogs, and other times there's a good mix of big dogs, puppies, and little guys.
author: David S.

description: Nice park and plenty of people with dogs and picking up after their dogs. Yes, human servants to their dogs. Great views of Bay and city. Enjoy the exterior of Danielle Steele's novel mansion. That side room of 1,00 sq. ft is for her various special occasion dresses. Close to CPMC medical center if you skin your knee running with your pooch. Has its own assigned city gardner, Ron Harwell, will be adding rosemary and lavender to the landscape mix.
author: miriam b.

description:
Puppies!!!! 

They put me in a much better mood than the huge textbooks I'm always carting up to this park. Until, of course, the day I tossed one of those textbooks down, spread out a towel and sat down in the sunshine to enjoy cute dogs, rare SF sunshine AND be productive.
So  I sat down, picked up the book and set it in my lap, ready to get down with some neurologic communicative disorders when suddenly I felt something on my fingers. Turning the book over, I discovered that I had actually tossed my pretty book right into a big pile of dog shit and then transferred that shit onto my jeans, my hands and my towel. Mothertruckersonofa.... ok, no need to freak out. Just go to the bathroom and clean up, right? Well even though by some miracle the bathroom wasn't locked, there was no soap. Of course. So I then made the rounds asking moms and dog owners for purell or a wipey or some effin thing to make me feel not so icky. Yes, I'm sure they thought I was a bit odd but if people cleaned up after their dogs, shit like this wouldn't happen. Or maybe if I paid attention to my surroundings....
Anyway, long story to say that I love this park for the dogs (minus their by products), the people watching, the view and the sunshine but I hate that the bathrooms are never open and now know that I need to bring my own damn soap.
author: deb C.

description: I live in-between Lafayette and Alta Plaza parks, yet spend 98% of my park time at Lafayette. There's plenty of lawn space to sprawl out for a picnic, sun-bathing, reading a book, or checking out the beautiful views of the city.
author: Chris B.

description: On a sunny afternoon, this is a recent fave for me... I head up with a towel and a book and get nice views and tons of cute dogs to look at (and sometimes play with).  As others have said, there are tennis courts and a little playground and such, but I've not partaken - for me, it's all about the fresh air and the generation of a little vitamin D.
author: Kristin D.

description: Loves it!  I have been spending lots of time here since the weather has been getting nicer.  I usually stop  by whole foods on California and pick up stuff for a picnic and then spend the afternoon laying out reading or talking with friends..  The tennis courts here are not the best ever but they are my favorite in the area because they are secluded and surrounded by trees, you kind of forget you live in a city.  Plus I have never had to wait more than 15 min for a court.  The views are amazing, it's a great place to take a walk with that  someone special for a romantic make out session....just don't hang out too late at night because there are probably some creepy people lurking.
author: Jessica H.

description: I love this park ..when I was growing up this.. was one of the spots to hang out if you were skipping school..I buried my Australian arowana fish here..figured the plants could used the fertilizer.  There are lots of plum trees here..but they never get sweet. I like eating them green with salt. The park is in a great neighborhood but you'll get your occasional bum.
author: John L.

description: I put on the heels, the Chanel, borrow my gbf's pom and come here. Then I realize I am turning in to my mother.
author: Anita B.

description: Small, clean, safe little spot of green in the midst of Pac Heights. It's a great place to spend time with the family. Little kids have lots of wide open spaces and playground equipment. Those same wide open spaces make this a haven for dog owners to bring Fido to socialize. Like any park, there is a path for runners and walkers and enough benches in the shade and sunshine.
author: Frances L.

description: It's a great little park to visit if you live in the area.  Plenty of people walking their dogs, and it has some nice views of the north bay since it's at the top of the hill at Pacific Heights.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Sehr schoener gemuetlich kleiner sauberer Park mit schoener Aussicht. Etwas snobbige Gegend vielleicht. Zumindest vom Clientel und den Huendchen. Zum in der Sonne ein Buch lesen opti. Mit Bier und Grill besser in den Golden Gate. Der Alta Plaza Park ist direkt daneben und liegt von der Aussicht noch etwas hoeher. Ist aber eher ein Spielplatz als ein klassischer Park.
author: Johannes B.

description: This place is pretty cool too.  Small and green with a mellow crowd.  Much smaller then Alta Plaza but it is a great dog park.
author: Carolyn D.

description: Very nice park to relax and bask in during the weekend. I found it particularly peaceful and the grass was very smooth and well maintained. Unlike Delores park, this park is clean and uncrowded. It also boasts a view from the top of the hill where you can see Alcatraz and a view of the bay. Quite a nice place to just wind down and have a picnic or bbq. I was also surprised to find parking near here as there really isn't much space to find one. If you're lazy about cooking out in the park, order in! I also recommend chucking a frisbee around. This place is a dog park and definitely a good place to view these furry creatures.
author: Dave Y.

description:
Positives: Good place to lay out, picnic, and relax (if you like dogs); nice views; can drink (on the sly)
Negatives: no bathrooms; lots of homeless; dogs everywhere (if you hate dogs); poop (not sure if its from the dogs or the homeless)
author: Matt A.

description: when i first discovered lafayette park, i mistook it for alamo square and ran around for over an hour looking for the painted ladies.  while i didn't find those victorians, i discovered a beautiful park with tennis courts, lovely greenery, and lots of happy looking dogs being walked by their happy looking parents.  set atop pac heights, there are beautiful views of down town from the park, and while parking in the area is hardly plentiful, i have better luck find spots up here than down around fillmore.
author: Roshni R.

description: I live two blocks from LP and walk by this park everyday. Finally decided to go sunbathing on a Saturday while walking my roommates dog, Jack Bauer. Two problems here: I was given specific rules to not let JB off his leash (while he is a cute boxer puppy, he is very very naughty. Known to eat people's food, which is not great when there are tables of picnickers around) and I forgot a towel and refused to lounge around in dog shit grass. So I instantly became "that girl" being dragged by an overly energetic dog who wanted to sniff other dogs butts, jump up and say hi to people, and chase after balls that do not belong to him. Agh! After almost ripping my arm out of its socket multiple times, Jack meets cute girl dog Morgan. Who is cute girl dog accompanied by? Cute boy. Cute boy and cute girl talk for an hour while dogs play. Cute boy lives around the corner from cute girl. Cute boy walks cute girl and cute dog home. While they see each other again? Who knows. But I have realized that having a dog is the fastest way to improve my love life. I didn't even need to lay out in my bikini to meet someone! Problem solved.
author: Lauren Y.
